results.title: Let's look at weeds
results.creator_credit: Larry Gosnell, ONF | NFB and Grant Crabtree
results.brief_description: During every growing season in Canada millions of acres of farmland and garden plots become a battlefield where weeds try to crowd out cultivated crops. This film is an ecological study of the relationship between weeds and crop plants, showing the life cycle of specific weeds, with reference to their susceptibility to cultural and chemical control. New developments in chemical weed killers are shown.

results.title: Let's look at railways
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Joan Boundy
results.brief_description: This film outlines the importance of railways to Australia. It shows the Australian railway system as an important means of transport for primary products, mail and people; traces the history of rail transport from the time of the Industrial Revolution; the effect of introducing railway transport in Australia; the break of gauge problems; the development of powerful locomotives in various states to cope with modern heavy haulages; the future of railways in Australia.

results.title: Let's look at radio: glimpses of programmes and personalities in the radio world
results.creator_credit: Australian Federation of Commercial Broadcasting Stations and James Pearson
results.brief_description: Gives glimpses of many of the best known radio entertainers in Australia and of popular programs being rehearsed and broadcast. The film emphasises that commercial broadcasting stations provide an entertainment service that is popular with the person in the street. it also shows how they provide the community with other services such as flood and fire warnings in country districts, police messages etc. Commentary: Jack Davey

results.title: Let's look at New Zealand
results.brief_description: The history, geography, customs and cities of New Zealand, and the economic and cultural development of its people. Includes houses and battlements of ancient warlike Maori tribes; cities of today; geological wonders including geysers and hot mud pools; agricultural wealth; leading national exports; and life of a typical Maori family.

results.title: Let's look at land
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian State Film Unit and Rodney Musch
results.brief_description: An information film designed to attract service industries to Tasmania. It deals with various industrial planning zones throughout the State mentioning the attendant advantages of establishing light industries in these zones.

results.title: Let's keep food safe to eat
results.brief_description: Shows two children practising good health with their food habits, such as washing hands before each meal, keeping food refrigerated and protecting food from flies and other contamination. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: Let's have a holiday
results.brief_description: Join the Silly Billies as they go on holiday to an amazing place called FUN FUN FUN. Once there you’ll see the Ashton Super Acrobats, play games and dance and sing. Songs on the video include: “The Water safety song”, “The Silly Billies song”, “Fun fun fun”, “The Boogie Woogie”, “Aussie rap”, “Miranda the Aussie kangaroo”, “The Electric crocodile”, “Dick the duck”, “Boxo the fox”, “Raise your hands and be happy”, “We can count to 20”, “Making up my milkshake” and “Ophelia the fairy”. Swimming coach Laurie Lawrence leads the children in “The Water safety song”.

results.title: Let's go to the movies
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures and Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
results.brief_description: Presents a general picture of the background, development and technical advances of the motion picture industry throughout the years. Shows stars and scenes from milestones of film history including Mary Pickford in “The Hills of Old Kentucky”, Charlie Chaplin in “Easy Street”, “The Great Train Robbery” the beginnings of the newsreel, the genesis of sound as exemplified by Al Jolson in “The Jazz Singer” and classical music from “Night Song”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: RKO Radio Pictures and Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

results.title: Let's go to Birmingham
results.brief_description: A train ride with a difference - at an equivalent speed of 960 m.p.h. Timelapse photography is used to record the Blue Pullman run from London to Birmingham to a musical background of Strauss’s “Perpetuum Mobile”. Time lapse sequences of the complicated track in front of the Pullman are photographed from the driver’s window and inter-cut with contrasting glimpses of the passengers taken at normal speed. Photography by Jack West. This film is an up-to-date version of an earlier film “London to Brighton in Four Minutes” (Title Code 006440) produced for television by the BBC.
